001package squidpony;
002
003import regexodus.*;
004import squidpony.squidmath.*;
005
006import java.io.Serializable;
007import java.util.ArrayList;
008import java.util.Collection;
009import java.util.Iterator;
010import java.util.Map;
011
012import static squidpony.Maker.makeList;
013import static squidpony.Maker.makeOM;
014
015/**
016 * A text processing class that can swap out occurrences of words and replace them with their synonyms.
017 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 5/23/2016.
018 */
019public class Thesaurus implements Serializable{
020    private static final long serialVersionUID = 3387639905758074640L;
021    protected static final Pattern wordMatch = Pattern.compile("([\\pL`]+)"),
022            similarFinder = Pattern.compile(".*?\\b(\\w\\w\\w\\w).*?{\\@1}.*$", "ui");
023    public OrderedMap<CharSequence, GapShuffler<String>> mappings;
024    public ArrayList<FakeLanguageGen.Alteration> alterations = new ArrayList<>(4);
025    protected GWTRNG rng;
026    public transient ArrayList<FakeLanguageGen> randomLanguages = new ArrayList<>(2);
027    public transient String latestGenerated = "Nationia";
028    /**
029     * Constructs a new Thesaurus with an unseeded RNG used to shuffle word order.
030     */
031    public Thesaurus()
032    {
033        mappings = new OrderedMap<>(256, Hashers.caseInsensitiveStringHasher);
034        rng = new GWTRNG();
035    }
036
037    /**
038     * Constructs a new Thesaurus, seeding its RNG (used to shuffle word order) with the next long from the given RNG.
039     * @param rng an RNG that will only be used to get one long (for seeding this class' RNG)
040     */
041    public Thesaurus(IRNG rng)
042    {
043        mappings = new OrderedMap<>(256, Hashers.caseInsensitiveStringHasher);
044        this.rng = new GWTRNG(rng.nextLong());
045    }
046
047    /**
048     * Constructs a new Thesaurus, seeding its RNG (used to shuffle word order) with shuffleSeed.
049     * @param shuffleSeed a long for seeding this class' RNG
050     */
051    public Thesaurus(long shuffleSeed)
052    {
053        mappings = new OrderedMap<>(256, Hashers.caseInsensitiveStringHasher);
054        this.rng = new GWTRNG(shuffleSeed);
055    }
056
057
058    /**
059     * Constructs a new Thesaurus, seeding its RNG (used to shuffle word order) with shuffleSeed.
060     * @param shuffleSeed a String for seeding this class' RNG
061     */
062    public Thesaurus(String shuffleSeed)
063    {
064        mappings = new OrderedMap<>(256, Hashers.caseInsensitiveStringHasher);
065        this.rng = new GWTRNG(CrossHash.hash64(shuffleSeed));
066    }
067
068    /**
069     * Allows this Thesaurus to find the exact words in synonyms and, when requested, replace each occurrence with a
070     * different word from the same Collection. Each word in synonyms should have the same part of speech, so "demon"
071     * and "devils" should not be in the same list of synonyms (singular noun and plural noun), but "demon" and "devil"
072     * could be (each is a singular noun). The Strings in synonyms should all be lower-case, since case is picked up
073     * from the text as it is being replaced and not from the words themselves. Proper nouns should normally not be used
074     * as synonyms, since this could get very confusing if it changed occurrences of "Germany" to "France" at random and
075     * a character's name, like "Dorothy", to "Anne", "Emily", "Cynthia", etc. in the middle of a section about Dorothy.
076     * The word matching pattern this uses only matches all-letter words, not words that contain hyphens, apostrophes,
077     * or other punctuation.
078     * @param synonyms a Collection of lower-case Strings with similar meaning and the same part of speech
079     * @return this for chaining
080     */
081    public Thesaurus addSynonyms(Collection<String> synonyms)
082    {
083        if(synonyms.isEmpty())
084            return this;
085        long prevState = rng.getState();
086        rng.setState(CrossHash.hash64(synonyms));
087        GapShuffler<String> shuffler = new GapShuffler<>(synonyms, rng);
088        for(String syn : synonyms)
089        {
090            mappings.put(syn, shuffler);
091        }
092        rng.setState(prevState);
093        return this;
094    }
095
096    public Thesaurus addReplacement(CharSequence before, String after)
097    {
098        mappings.put(before, new GapShuffler<String>(after));
099        return this;
100    }
101
102    /**
103     * Allows this Thesaurus to replace a specific keyword, typically containing multiple backtick characters ('`') so
104     * it can't be confused with a "real word," with one of the words in synonyms (chosen in shuffled order). The
105     * backtick is the only punctuation character that this class' word matcher considers part of a word, both for this
106     * reason and because it is rarely used in English text.
107     * @param keyword a word (typically containing backticks, '`') that will be replaced by a word from synonyms
108     * @param synonyms a Collection of lower-case Strings with similar meaning and the same part of speech
109     * @return this for chaining
110     */
111    public Thesaurus addCategory(String keyword, Collection<String> synonyms)
112    {
113        if(synonyms.isEmpty())
114            return this;
115        long prevState = rng.getState();
116        rng.setState(CrossHash.hash64(synonyms));
117        GapShuffler<String> shuffler = new GapShuffler<>(synonyms, rng);
118        mappings.put(keyword, shuffler);
119        rng.setState(prevState);
120        return this;
121    }
122
123    /**
124     * Adds several pre-made categories to this Thesaurus' known categories, but won't cause it to try to replace normal
125     * words with synonyms (only categories, which contain backticks in the name). The keywords this currently knows,
126     * and the words it will replace those keywords with, are:
127     * <br>
128     * (THIS IS OUT OF DATE, THERE ARE MORE KNOWN.)
129     * <br>
130     * <ul>
131     *     <li>"calm`adj`": harmonious, peaceful, pleasant, serene, placid, tranquil, calm</li>
132     *     <li>"calm`noun`": harmony, peace, kindness, serenity, tranquility, calm</li>
133     *     <li>"org`noun`": fraternity, brotherhood, order, group, foundation, association, guild, fellowship, partnership</li>
134     *     <li>"org`nouns`": fraternities, brotherhoods, orders, groups, foundations, associations, guilds, fellowships, partnerships</li>
135     *     <li>"empire`adj`": imperial, prince's, king's, sultan's, regal, dynastic, royal, hegemonic, monarchic, ascendant, emir's, lordly</li>
136     *     <li>"empire`noun`": empire, emirate, kingdom, sultanate, dominion, dynasty, imperium, hegemony, triumvirate, ascendancy, monarchy, commonwealth</li>
137     *     <li>"empire`nouns`": empires, emirates, kingdoms, sultanates, dominions, dynasties, imperia, hegemonies, triumvirates, ascendancies, monarchies, commonwealths</li>
138     *     <li>"union`adj`": united, allied, people's, confederated, federated, congressional, independent, associated, unified, democratic</li>
139     *     <li>"union`noun`": union, alliance, coalition, confederation, federation, congress, confederacy, league, faction, republic</li>
140     *     <li>"union`nouns`": unions, alliances, coalitions, confederations, federations, congresses, confederacies, leagues, factions, republics</li>
141     *     <li>"militia`noun`": rebellion, resistance, militia, liberators, warriors, fighters, militants, front, irregulars</li>
142     *     <li>"militia`nouns`": rebellions, resistances, militias, liberators, warriors, fighters, militants, fronts, irregulars</li>
143     *     <li>"gang`noun`": gang, syndicate, mob, crew, posse, mafia, cartel</li>
144     *     <li>"gang`nouns`": gangs, syndicates, mobs, crews, posses, mafias, cartels</li>
145     *     <li>"duke`noun`": duke, earl, baron, fief, lord, shogun</li>
146     *     <li>"duke`nouns`": dukes, earls, barons, fiefs, lords, shoguns</li>
147     *     <li>"duchy`noun`": duchy, earldom, barony, fiefdom, lordship, shogunate</li>
148     *     <li>"duchy`nouns`": duchies, earldoms, baronies, fiefdoms, lordships, shogunates</li>
149     *     <li>"magical`adj`": arcane, enchanted, sorcerous, ensorcelled, magical, mystical</li>
150     *     <li>"holy`adj`": auspicious, divine, holy, sacred, prophetic, blessed, godly</li>
151     *     <li>"unholy`adj`": bewitched, occult, unholy, macabre, accursed, profane, vile</li>
152     *     <li>"forest`adj`": natural, primal, verdant, lush, fertile, bountiful</li>
153     *     <li>"forest`noun`": nature, forest, greenery, jungle, woodland, grove, copse</li>
154     *     <li>"fancy`adj`": grand, glorious, magnificent, magnanimous, majestic, great, powerful</li>
155     *     <li>"evil`adj`": heinous, scurrilous, terrible, horrible, debased, wicked, evil, malevolent, nefarious, vile</li>
156     *     <li>"good`adj`": righteous, moral, good, pure, compassionate, flawless, perfect</li>
157     *     <li>"sinister`adj`": shadowy, silent, lethal, deadly, fatal, venomous, cutthroat, murderous, bloodstained, stalking</li>
158     *     <li>"sinister`noun`": shadow, silence, assassin, ninja, venom, poison, snake, murder, blood, razor, tiger</li>
159     *     <li>"blade`noun`": blade, knife, sword, axe, stiletto, katana, scimitar, hatchet, spear, glaive, halberd,
160     *               hammer, maul, flail, mace, sickle, scythe, whip, lance, nunchaku, saber, cutlass, trident</li>
161     *     <li>"bow`noun`": bow, longbow, shortbow, crossbow, sling, atlatl, bolas, javelin, net, shuriken, dagger</li>
162     *     <li>"weapon`noun`": blade, knife, sword, axe, stiletto, katana, scimitar, hatchet, spear, glaive, halberd,
163     *               hammer, maul, flail, mace, sickle, scythe, whip, lance, nunchaku, saber, cutlass, trident,
164     *               bow, longbow, shortbow, crossbow, sling, atlatl, bolas, javelin, net, shuriken, dagger</li>
165     *     <li>"musket`noun`": arquebus, blunderbuss, musket, matchlock, flintlock, wheellock, cannon</li>
166     *     <li>"grenade`noun`": rocket, grenade, missile, bomb, warhead, explosive, flamethrower</li>
167     *     <li>"rifle`noun`": pistol, rifle, handgun, firearm, longarm, shotgun</li>
168     *     <li>"blade`nouns`": blades, knives, swords, axes, stilettos, katana, scimitars, hatchets, spears, glaives, halberds,
169     *               hammers, mauls, flails, maces, sickles, scythes, whips, lances, nunchaku, sabers, cutlasses, tridents</li>
170     *     <li>"bow`nouns`": bows, longbows, shortbows, crossbows, slings, atlatls, bolases, javelins, nets, shuriken, daggers</li>
171     *     <li>"weapon`nouns`": blades, knives, swords, axes, stilettos, katana, scimitars, hatchets, spears, glaives, halberds,
172     *               hammers, mauls, flails, maces, sickles, scythes, whips, lances, nunchaku, sabers, cutlasses, tridents,
173     *               bows, longbows, shortbows, crossbows, slings, atlatls, bolases, javelins, nets, shuriken, daggers</li>
174     *     <li>"musket`nouns`": arquebusses, blunderbusses, muskets, matchlocks, flintlocks, wheellocks, cannons</li>
175     *     <li>"grenade`nouns`": rockets, grenades, missiles, bombs, warheads, explosives, flamethrowers</li>
176     *     <li>"rifle`nouns`": pistols, rifles, handguns, firearms, longarms, shotguns</li>
177     *     <li>"tech`adj`": cyber, digital, electronic, techno, hacker, crypto, turbo, mechanical, servo</li>
178     *     <li>"sole`adj`": sole, true, singular, total, ultimate, final, last</li>
179     *     <li>"light`adj`": bright, glowing, solar, stellar, lunar, radiant, luminous, shimmering</li>
180     *     <li>"light`noun`": light, glow, sun, star, moon, radiance, dawn, torch</li>
181     *     <li>"light`nouns`": lights, glimmers, suns, stars, moons, torches</li>
182     *     <li>"smart`adj`": brilliant, smart, genius, wise, clever, cunning, mindful, aware</li>
183     *     <li>"smart`noun`": genius, wisdom, cunning, awareness, mindfulness, acumen, smarts, knowledge</li>
184     *     <li>"bandit`noun`": thief, raider, bandit, rogue, brigand, highwayman, pirate</li>
185     *     <li>"bandit`nouns`": thieves, raiders, bandits, rogues, brigands, highwaymen, pirates</li>
186     *     <li>"guard`noun`": protector, guardian, warden, defender, guard, shield, sentinel, watchman, knight</li>
187     *     <li>"guard`nouns`": protectors, guardians, wardens, defenders, guards, shields, sentinels, watchmen, knights</li>
188     *     <li>"rage`noun`": rage, fury, anger, wrath, frenzy, vengeance</li>
189     * </ul>
190     * Capitalizing the first letter in the keyword where it appears in text you call process() on will capitalize the
191     * first letter of the produced fake word. Capitalizing the second letter will capitalize the whole produced fake
192     * word. This applies only per-instance of each keyword; it won't change the internally-stored list of words.
193     * @return this for chaining
194     */
195    public Thesaurus addKnownCategories()
196    {
197        for(Map.Entry<String, ArrayList<String>> kv : categories.entrySet())
198        {
199            addCategory(kv.getKey(), kv.getValue());
200        }
201        return this;
202    }
203
204    /**
205     * Adds a large list of words pre-generated by FakeLanguageGen and hand-picked for fitness, and makes them
206     * accessible with a keyword based on the language and any tweaks made to it. The keywords this currently knows:
207     * <br>
208     * <ul>
209     *     <li>"jp`gen`": Imitation Japanese</li>
210     *     <li>"fr`gen`": Imitation French; contains some accented chars</li>
211     *     <li>"gr`gen`": Imitation Greek (romanized)</li>
212     *     <li>"ru`gen`": Imitation Russian (romanized)</li>
213     *     <li>"sw`gen`": Imitation Swahili</li>
214     *     <li>"so`gen`": Imitation Somali</li>
215     *     <li>"en`gen`": Imitation English (not very good on its own)</li>
216     *     <li>"ar`gen`": Imitation Arabic (better); doesn't have accents and should be more readable</li>
217     *     <li>"nr`gen`": Imitation Old Norse (using simpler and easier-to-pronounce spelling)</li>
218     *     <li>"nr`acc`gen`": Imitation Old Norse (using the uncommon letters used in modern Icelandic)</li>
219     *     <li>"hi`gen`": Imitation Hindi (romanized and with accents removed)</li>
220     *     <li>"kr`gen`": Imitation Korean (romanized)</li>
221     *     <li>"na`gen`": Imitation Nahuatl (spelled like how Spanish loanwords from Nahuatl are spelled)</li>
222     *     <li>"mn`gen`": Imitation Mongolian (the form of the language from medieval times, romanized)</li>
223     *     <li>"in`gen`": Imitation Inuktitut (romanized)</li>
224     *     <li>"si`gen`": "Simplish" (simplified imitation English, without special word endings like "-ight")</li>
225     *     <li>"fn`gen`": Fantasy Names; styled after the possibly-Europe-like names common in fantasy books</li>
226     *     <li>"fn`acc`gen`": Fancy Fantasy Names; the same as "fn`gen`", but with lots of accented chars</li>
227     *     <li>"lc`gen`": Lovecraft; styled after the names of creatures from H.P. Lovecraft's Cthulhu Mythos</li>
228     *     <li>"el`gen`": Elf, modeled after J.R.R. Tolkien's languages for elves</li>
229     *     <li>"gb`gen`": Goblin, fantasy language of sneaky species</li>
230     *     <li>"if`gen`": Infernal, fantasy language of clever and subtle fiends</li>
231     *     <li>"dm`gen`": Demonic, fantasy language of brutish fiends</li>
232     *     <li>"al`a`gen`": Alien A, fantasy language with very unusual consonants</li>
233     *     <li>"al`e`gen`": Alien E, fantasy language with click sounds but no "lip sounds"</li>
234     *     <li>"al`i`gen`": Alien I, fantasy language with many tones and "liquid sounds"</li>
235     *     <li>"al`o`gen`": Alien O, fantasy language with long words and lengthy vowel clusters</li>
236     *     <li>"al`u`gen`": Alien U, fantasy language with many accented consonants and different suffixes</li>
237     *     <li>"ru`so`gen`": Mix of imitation Russian (75%) and Somali (25%)</li>
238     *     <li>"gr`hi`gen`": Mix of imitation Greek (50%) and Hindi (accents removed, 50%)</li>
239     *     <li>"sw`fr`gen`": Mix of imitation Swahili (70%) and French (30%)</li>
240     *     <li>"ar`jp`gen`": Mix of imitation Arabic (accents removed, 60%) and Japanese (40%)</li>
241     *     <li>"sw`gr`gen`": Mix of imitation Swahili (60%) and Greek (40%)</li>
242     *     <li>"gr`so`gen`": Mix of imitation Greek (60%) and Somali (40%)</li>
243     *     <li>"en`hi`gen`": Mix of imitation English (60%) and Hindi (accents removed, 40%)</li>
244     *     <li>"en`jp`gen`": Mix of imitation English (60%) and Japanese (40%)</li>
245     *     <li>"so`hi`gen`": Mix of imitation Somali (60%) and Hindi (accents removed, 40%)</li>
246     *     <li>"ru`gr`gen`": Mix of imitation Russian (60%) and Greek (40%)</li>
247     *     <li>"lc`gr`gen`": Mix of Lovecraft-styled names (60%) and imitation Russian (40%)</li>
248     *     <li>"fr`mod`gen`": Imitation French; modified to replace doubled consonants like "gg" with "gsh" or similar</li>
249     *     <li>"jp`mod`gen`": Imitation Japanese; modified to sometimes double vowels from "a" to "aa" or similar</li>
250     *     <li>"so`mod`gen`": Imitation Somali (not really); modified beyond recognition and contains accents</li>
251     * </ul>
252     * Capitalizing the first letter in the keyword where it appears in text you call process() on will capitalize the
253     * first letter of the produced fake word, which is often desirable for things like place names. Capitalizing the
254     * second letter will capitalize the whole produced fake word. This applies only per-instance of each keyword; it
255     * won't change the internally-stored list of words.
256     * @return this for chaining
257     */
258    public Thesaurus addFakeWords()
259    {
260        long state = rng.getState();
261        for(Map.Entry<CharSequence, FakeLanguageGen> kv : languages.entrySet())
262        {
263            ArrayList<String> words = new ArrayList<>(16);
264            for (int i = 0; i < 16; i++) {
265                words.add(kv.getValue().word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4)));
266            }
267            addCategory(StringKit.replace(kv.getKey(), "gen", "pre"), words);
268        }
269        rng.setState(state);
270        return this;
271    }
272
273    private StringBuilder modify(CharSequence text)
274    {
275        Matcher m;
276        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(text);
277        Replacer.StringBuilderBuffer tb, working = Replacer.wrap(sb);
278        StringBuilder tmp;
279        boolean found;
280        FakeLanguageGen.Alteration alt;
281        for (int a = 0; a < alterations.size(); a++) {
282            alt = alterations.get(a);
283            tmp = working.sb;
284            tb = Replacer.wrap(new StringBuilder(tmp.length()));
285            m = alt.replacer.getPattern().matcher(tmp);
286
287            found = false;
288            while (true) {
289                if (rng.nextDouble() < alt.chance) {
290                    if (!Replacer.replaceStep(m, alt.replacer.getSubstitution(), tb))
291                        break;
292                    found = true;
293                } else {
294                    if (!m.find())
295                        break;
296                    found = true;
297                    m.getGroup(MatchResult.PREFIX, tb);
298                    m.getGroup(MatchResult.MATCH, tb);
299                    m.setTarget(m, MatchResult.SUFFIX);
300                }
301            }
302            if (found) {
303                m.getGroup(MatchResult.TARGET, tb);
304                working = tb;
305            }
306        }
307        return working.sb;
308
309    }
310    /**
311     * Given a String, StringBuilder, or other CharSequence that should contain words this knows synonyms for, this
312     * replaces each occurrence of such a known word with one of its synonyms, leaving unknown words untouched. Words
313     * that were learned together as synonyms with addSynonyms() will be replaced in such a way that an individual
314     * replacement word should not occur too close to a previous occurrence of the same word; that is, replacing the
315     * text "You fiend! You demon! You despoiler of creation; devil made flesh!", where "fiend", "demon", and "devil"
316     * are all synonyms, would never produce a string that contained "fiend" as the replacement for all three of those.
317     * @param text a CharSequence, such as a String, that contains words in the source language
318     * @return a String of the translated text.
319     */
320    public String process(CharSequence text)
321    {
322        Replacer rep = wordMatch.replacer(new SynonymSubstitution());
323        if(alterations.isEmpty())
324            return rep.replace(text);
325        else
326            return modify(rep.replace(text)).toString();
327    }
328
329    public String lookup(String word)
330    {
331        if(word.isEmpty())
332            return word;
333        String word2 = word.toLowerCase();
334        if(mappings.containsKey(word2))
335        {
336            String nx = mappings.get(word2).next();
337            if(nx.isEmpty())
338                return nx;
339            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
340                return nx.toUpperCase();
341            if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
342            {
343                return Character.toUpperCase(nx.charAt(0)) + nx.substring(1);
344            }
345            return nx;
346        }
347        else if(languages.containsKey(word2))
348        {
349            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
350                return languages.get(word2).word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4)).toUpperCase();
351            if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
352            {
353                return languages.get(word2).word(rng, true, rng.between(2, 4));
354            }
355            return languages.get(word2).word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4));
356        }
357        return word;
358    }
359
360    private class SynonymSubstitution implements Substitution
361    {
362        private StringBuilder temp = new StringBuilder(64);
363        @Override
364        public void appendSubstitution(MatchResult match, TextBuffer dest) {
365            //dest.append(lookup(match.group(0)));
366            temp.setLength(0);
367            match.getGroup(0, temp);
368            writeLookup(dest, temp);
369        }
370    }
371
372    private void writeLookup(TextBuffer dest, StringBuilder word) {
373        if(word.length() <= 0)
374            return;
375        if(mappings.containsKey(word))
376        {
377            String nx = mappings.get(word).next();
378            if(nx.isEmpty())
379                return;
380            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
381            {
382                dest.append(nx.toUpperCase());
383                return;
384            }
385            if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
386            {
387                dest.append(Character.toUpperCase(nx.charAt(0)));
388                dest.append(nx.substring(1));
389                return;
390            }
391            dest.append(nx);
392            return;
393        }
394        else if(languages.containsKey(word))
395        {
396            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
397            {
398                dest.append(languages.get(word).word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4)).toUpperCase());
399            }
400            else if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
401            {
402                dest.append(languages.get(word).word(rng, true, rng.between(2, 4)));
403            }
404            else
405            {
406                dest.append(languages.get(word).word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4)));
407            }
408            return;
409        }
410        else if(numbers.containsKey(word))
411        {
412            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
413            {
414                dest.append(numberWordInRange(2, numbers.get(word)).toUpperCase());
415            }
416            else if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
417            {
418                String w = numberWordInRange(2, numbers.get(word));
419                dest.append(Character.toUpperCase(w.charAt(0)));
420                dest.append(w.substring(1));
421            }
422            else
423            {
424                dest.append(numberWordInRange(2, numbers.get(word)));
425            }
426            return;
427        }
428        else if(numberAdjectives.containsKey(word))
429        {
430            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
431            {
432                dest.append(numberAdjectiveInRange(2, numberAdjectives.get(word)).toUpperCase());
433            }
434            else if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
435            {
436                String w = numberAdjectiveInRange(2, numberAdjectives.get(word));
437                dest.append(Character.toUpperCase(w.charAt(0)));
438                dest.append(w.substring(1));
439            }
440            else
441            {
442                dest.append(numberAdjectiveInRange(2, numberAdjectives.get(word)));
443            }
444            return;
445        }
446        if(dest instanceof Replacer.StringBuilderBuffer)
447        {
448            ((Replacer.StringBuilderBuffer)dest).sb.append(word);
449        }
450        else
451            dest.append(word.toString());
452
453    }
454
455    private class RandomLanguageSubstitution implements Substitution
456    {
457        @Override
458        public void appendSubstitution(MatchResult match, TextBuffer dest) {
459            FakeLanguageGen lang = FakeLanguageGen.randomLanguage(rng.nextLong());
460            randomLanguages.add(lang);
461            if(match.isCaptured(1))
462            {
463                lang = FakeLanguageGen.randomLanguage(rng.nextLong());
464                randomLanguages.add(lang);
465                do {
466                    latestGenerated = randomLanguages.get(0).word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)))
467                            + "-" + randomLanguages.get(1).word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)));
468                }while (latestGenerated.length() <= 5 || latestGenerated.length() >= 17);
469                dest.append(latestGenerated);
470            }
471            else
472            {
473                do{
474                    latestGenerated = lang.word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)));
475                }while (latestGenerated.length() <= 2 || latestGenerated.length() >= 11);
476                dest.append(latestGenerated);
477            }
478        }
479    }
480
481    private class KnownLanguageSubstitution implements Substitution
482    {
483        public FakeLanguageGen language;
484        public KnownLanguageSubstitution(FakeLanguageGen lang)
485        {
486            language = lang;
487        }
488        @Override
489        public void appendSubstitution(MatchResult match, TextBuffer dest) {
490            if (match.isCaptured(1)) {
491                do
492                {
493                    latestGenerated = language.word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5))) +
494                            "-" + language.word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)));
495                }while (latestGenerated.length() <= 5 || latestGenerated.length() >= 17);
496                dest.append(latestGenerated);
497            } else
498            {
499                do{
500                    latestGenerated = language.word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)));
501                }while (latestGenerated.length() <= 2 || latestGenerated.length() >= 11);
502                dest.append(latestGenerated);
503            }
504        }
505    }
506
507    /**
508     * Generates a random possible name for a nation, such as "Iond-Gouccief Alliance" or "The Last Drayo Commonwealth".
509     * Needs {@link #addKnownCategories()} to be called on this Thesaurus first. May use accented characters, as in
510     * "Thùdshù-Hyóttiálb Hegemony" or "The Glorious Chô Empire"; if you want to strip these out and replace accented
511     * chars with their un-accented counterparts, you can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which
512     * returns a CharSequence that can be converted to String if needed. Shortly after calling this method, but before
513     * calling it again, you can retrieve the generated random languages, if any were used while making nation names, by
514     * getting the FakeLanguageGen elements of this class' {@link #randomLanguages} field. Using one of these
515     * FakeLanguageGen objects, you can produce many more words with a similar style to the nation name, like "Drayo" in
516     * "The Last Drayo Commonwealth". If more than one language was used in the nation name, as in "Thùdshù-Hyóttiálb
517     * Hegemony", you will have two languages in randomLanguages, so here "Thùdshù" would be generated by the first
518     * language, and "Hyóttiálb" by the second language. Calling this method replaces the current contents of
519     * randomLanguages, so if you want to use those languages, get them while you can. This also assigns the
520     * {@link #latestGenerated} field to contain the part of the nation name without any larger titles; in the case of
521     * "The Glorious Chô Empire", the latestGenerated field would be assigned "Chô" at the same time the longer name
522     * would be returned. This field will be reassigned if this method is called again.
523     *
524     * @return a random name for a nation or a loose equivalent to a nation, as a String
525     */
526    public String makeNationName()
527    {
528        String working = process(rng.getRandomElement(nationTerms));
529        int frustration = 0;
530        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
531            working = process(rng.getRandomElement(nationTerms));
532        randomLanguages.clear();
533        RandomLanguageSubstitution sub = new RandomLanguageSubstitution();
534        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
535        return replacer.replace(working);
536    }
537    /**
538     * Generates a random possible name for a nation, such as "Iond-Gouccief Alliance" or "The Last Drayo Commonwealth",
539     * with the FakeLanguageGen already available instead of randomly created. Needs {@link #addKnownCategories()} to be
540     * called on this Thesaurus first. May use accented characters, as in "Thùdshù Hegemony" or "The Glorious Chô
541     * Empire", if the given language can produce them; if you want to strip these out and replace accented chars
542     * with their un-accented counterparts, you can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which
543     * returns a CharSequence that can be converted to String if needed, or simply get an accent-less language by
544     * calling {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents()} on the FakeLanguageGen you would give this. This assigns the
545     * {@link #latestGenerated} field to contain the part of the nation name without any larger titles; in the case of
546     * "The Glorious Chô Empire", the latestGenerated field would be assigned "Chô" at the same time the longer name
547     * would be returned. This field will be reassigned if this method is called again.
548     * <br>
549     * Some nation names use a hyphenated pairing of what would normally be names in two different languages; if one of
550     * those names is produced by this it will produce two names in the same linguistic style. The randomLanguages field
551     * is not populated by this method; it is assumed that since you are passing this a FakeLanguageGen, you already
552     * have the one you want to use anyway.
553     *
554     * @param language a FakeLanguageGen that will be used to construct any non-English names
555     * @return a random name for a nation or a loose equivalent to a nation, as a String
556     */
557    public String makeNationName(FakeLanguageGen language)
558    {
559        String working = process(rng.getRandomElement(nationTerms));
560        int frustration = 0;
561        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
562            working = process(rng.getRandomElement(nationTerms));
563        randomLanguages.clear();
564        KnownLanguageSubstitution sub = new KnownLanguageSubstitution(language);
565        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
566        return replacer.replace(working);
567    }
568
569    /**
570     * Generates a random possible name for a plant or tree, such as "Ikesheha's maple" or "sugarleaf birch".
571     * Needs {@link #addKnownCategories()} to be called on this Thesaurus first.
572     * called on this Thesaurus first. May use accented characters, as in "Emôa's greenwood", if the given language can
573     * produce them; if you want to strip these out and replace accented chars with their un-accented counterparts, you
574     * can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which returns a CharSequence that can be converted
575     * to String if needed. Shortly after calling this method, but before
576     * calling it again, you can retrieve the generated random languages, if any were used while making names, by
577     * getting the FakeLanguageGen elements of this class' {@link #randomLanguages} field. Using one of these
578     * FakeLanguageGen objects, you can produce many more words with a similar style to the person or place name, like
579     * "Drayo" in "The Last Drayo Commonwealth". Calling this method replaces the current contents of
580     * randomLanguages, so if you want to use those languages, get them while you can.
581     *
582     * @return a random name for a plant, shrub, or tree, as a String
583     */
584    public String makePlantName()
585    {
586        String working = process(rng.getRandomElement(plantTerms));
587        int frustration = 0;
588        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
589            working = process(rng.getRandomElement(plantTerms));
590        randomLanguages.clear();
591        RandomLanguageSubstitution sub = new RandomLanguageSubstitution();
592        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
593        return replacer.replace(working).replace("\t", "");
594    }
595    /**
596     * Generates a random possible name for a plant or tree, such as "Ikesheha's maple" or "sugarleaf birch",
597     * with the FakeLanguageGen already available instead of randomly created. Needs {@link #addKnownCategories()} to be
598     * called on this Thesaurus first. May use accented characters, as in "Emôa's greenwood", if the given language can
599     * produce them; if you want to strip these out and replace accented chars with their un-accented counterparts, you
600     * can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which
601     * returns a CharSequence that can be converted to String if needed, or simply get an accent-less language by
602     * calling {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents()} on the FakeLanguageGen you would give this.
603     *
604     * @param language a FakeLanguageGen that will be used to construct any non-English names
605     * @return a random name for a plant, shrub, or tree, as a String
606     */
607    public String makePlantName(FakeLanguageGen language)
608    {
609        String working = process(rng.getRandomElement(plantTerms));
610        int frustration = 0;
611        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
612            working = process(rng.getRandomElement(plantTerms));
613        randomLanguages.clear();
614        KnownLanguageSubstitution sub = new KnownLanguageSubstitution(language);
615        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
616        return replacer.replace(working).replace("\t", "");
617    }
618
619    /**
620     * Gets an English word for a given number, if this knows it. These words are known from 0 ("zero") to 20
621     * ("twenty"), as well as some higher numbers. If a word isn't known for a number, this returns the number as a
622     * String, such as "537" or "-1".
623     * @param number the number to get a word for
624     * @return the word associated with a number as a String, or if none is known, {@code String.valueOf(number)}.
625     */
626    public static String numberWord(final int number)
627    {
628        switch (number){
629            case 0: return "zero";
630            case 1: return "one";
631            case 2: return "two";
632            case 3: return "three";
633            case 4: return "four";
634            case 5: return "five";
635            case 6: return "six";
636            case 7: return "seven";
637            case 8: return "eight";
638            case 9: return "nine";
639            case 10: return "ten";
640            case 11: return "eleven";
641            case 12: return "twelve";
642            case 13: return "thirteen";
643            case 14: return "fourteen";
644            case 15: return "fifteen";
645            case 16: return "sixteen";
646            case 17: return "seventeen";
647            case 18: return "eighteen";
648            case 19: return "nineteen";
649            case 20: return "twenty";
650            case 30: return "thirty";
651            case 40: return "fourty";
652            case 50: return "fifty";
653            case 60: return "sixty";
654            case 70: return "seventy";
655            case 80: return "eighty";
656            case 90: return "ninety";
657            case 100: return "hundred";
658            case 1000: return "thousand";
659            case 1000000: return "million";
660            case 1000000000: return "billion";
661            default: return String.valueOf(number);
662        }
663    }
664
665    /**
666     * Gets an English word that describes a numbered position in some sequence, if this knows it (such as "second" or
667     * "eleventh"). These words are known from 1 ("first") to 20 ("twentieth"), as well as some higher numbers. If a
668     * word isn't known for a number, this appends a suffix based on the last base-10 digit to the number, as with "0th"
669     * or "42nd".
670     * @param number the number to get a position adjective for
671     * @return the word associated with a number as a String, or if none is known, {@code String.valueOf(number)} followed by a two-char suffix from the last digit.
672     */
673    public static String numberAdjective(final int number)
674    {
675        switch (number){
676            case 1: return "first";
677            case 2: return "second";
678            case 3: return "third";
679            case 4: return "fourth";
680            case 5: return "fifth";
681            case 6: return "sixth";
682            case 7: return "seventh";
683            case 8: return "eighth";
684            case 9: return "ninth";
685            case 10: return "tenth";
686            case 11: return "eleventh";
687            case 12: return "twelfth";
688            case 13: return "thirteenth";
689            case 14: return "fourteenth";
690            case 15: return "fifteenth";
691            case 16: return "sixteenth";
692            case 17: return "seventeenth";
693            case 18: return "eighteenth";
694            case 19: return "nineteenth";
695            case 20: return "twentieth";
696            case 30: return "thirtieth";
697            case 40: return "fourtieth";
698            case 50: return "fiftieth";
699            case 60: return "sixtieth";
700            case 70: return "seventieth";
701            case 80: return "eightieth";
702            case 90: return "ninetieth";
703            case 100: return "hundredth";
704            case 1000: return "thousandth";
705            case 1000000: return "millionth";
706            case 1000000000: return "billionth";
707            default: 
708            {
709                switch (number % 10){
710                    case 1: return number + "st";
711                    case 2: return number + "nd";
712                    case 3: return number + "rd";
713                    default:return number + "th";
714                }
715            }
716        }
717    }
718
719    /**
720     * Gets an English word for a number, if this knows it, where the number is chosen randomly between lowest and
721     * highest, both inclusive. These words are known from 0 ("zero") to 20 ("twenty"), as well as some higher numbers.
722     * If a word isn't known for a number, this returns the number as a String, such as "537" or "-1".
723     * @param lowest the lower bound for numbers this can choose, inclusive
724     * @param highest the upper bound for numbers this can choose, inclusive
725     * @return a String word for a number in the given range, such as "six" or "eleven", if it is known
726     */
727    public String numberWordInRange(int lowest, int highest)
728    {
729        return numberWord(rng.nextSignedInt(highest + 1 - lowest) + lowest);
730    }
731    /**
732     * Gets an English word that describes a numbered position in some sequence, if this knows it (such as "second" or
733     * "eleventh"), where the number is chosen randomly between lowest and highest, both inclusive. These words are
734     * known from 1 ("first") to 20 ("twentieth"), as well as some output for other numbers (such as "42nd" or "23rd").
735     * @param lowest the lower bound for numbers this can choose, inclusive
736     * @param highest the upper bound for numbers this can choose, inclusive
737     * @return a String word for a number in the given range, such as "third" or "twelfth", if it is known
738     */
739    public String numberAdjectiveInRange(int lowest, int highest)
740    {
741        return numberAdjective(rng.nextSignedInt(highest + 1 - lowest) + lowest);
742    }

1211    /**
1212     * Thesaurus preset that changes all text to sound like this speaker: "Desaurus preset dat changez all text to sound
1213     * like dis speakah." You may be familiar with a certain sci-fi game that has orks who sound like this.
1214     */
1215    public static Thesaurus ORK = new Thesaurus("WAAAAAGH!");
1216    static {
1217        ORK.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("\\bth", "d"));
1218        ORK.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("th", "dd"));
1219        ORK.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("er\\b", "ah"));
1220        ORK.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("es\\b", "ez"));
1221        ORK.addReplacement("the", "da")
1222                .addReplacement("their", "deyr")
1223                .addReplacement("yes", "ya")
1224                .addReplacement("your", "youse")
1225                .addReplacement("yours", "youses")
1226                .addReplacement("going", "gon'")
1227                .addReplacement("and", "an'")
1228                .addReplacement("to", "*snort*")
1229                .addReplacement("rhythm", "riddim")
1230                .addReplacement("get", "git")
1231                .addReplacement("good", "gud");
1232        Iterator<String> it = adjective.keySet().iterator();
1233        while (it.hasNext()){
1234            if(!it.next().contains("`adj`"))
1235                it.remove();
1236        }
1237        it = noun.keySet().iterator();
1238        while (it.hasNext()){
1239            if(!it.next().contains("`noun`"))
1240                it.remove();
1241        }
1242        it = nouns.keySet().iterator();
1243        while (it.hasNext()){
1244            if(!it.next().contains("`nouns`"))
1245                it.remove();
1246        }
1247
1248
1249    }
